p: In general, Curcuma EOs are nontoxic, nonmutagenic, noncarcinogenic and nonphototoxic [ 125, 239]. Turmeric EO has been classified as generally recognized as safe (GRAS) [ 125]. Undiluted turmeric rhizome oil was slightly irritating to rabbits, but was not irritating to mice. When tested at 4% on 25 volunteers, it was neither irritating nor sensitizing [ 239]. There is a possible drug interaction when used orally, especially with antidiabetic medications [ 125]. The acute dermal LD 50 of turmeric rhizome oil was >5 g/kg in rabbits, and the acute oral LD 50 was >5 g/kg in rats [ 239]. When administered intraperitoneally (i.p.) at doses higher than 28 mg/kg/day, 20–36% of normal and streptococcal cell wall-injected animals died after two weeks of treatment, while lower vehicle or oil doses (≤2.8 mg/kg/day) caused no deaths [ 182]. Oral administration of a dose of turmeric oil that is 20-fold higher than the lowest effective i.p. doses was nontoxic [ 182]. No hazards or adverse skin reactions were reported for turmeric-leaf EO; however, the α-phellandrene chemotype might cause skin sensitization on oxidation.
